The museum can engage them through interactive sessions, in-depth talks, workshops, and meet-and-greet sessions with the author.

2. Book lovers: People who are fond of literature and enjoy reading books, especially art-related books. They attend author exhibitions or programs to explore the artist's work through the author's interpretations and analysis. 3. Students and scholars: This group comprises students pursuing art, history, or literature courses or scholars researching art or artist in specific. They attend author exhibitions or programs as part of their curriculum or research work. The museum can engage them by organizing expert panels or Q&A sessions with the authors, providing access to archive material, and facilitating research opportunities.

4. Tourists: People who visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art as part of their travel itinerary. They are likely to attend author exhibitions or programs that coincide with their visit. The museum can engage them through guided tours, interactive workshops, and special exhibitions.

The exhibition included over 400 works, including paintings, photographs, and installations. It was accompanied by a fully illustrated catalog with essays from leading art historians and an exhibition-related program featuring talks, tours, and workshops.

The exhibition catalog featured essays and insights from art historians and scholars, and the accompanying program included talks, tours, and workshops.

3. Views and Re-Views: Soviet Political Posters and Cartoons (2012): This exhibition explored the role of political propaganda in the Soviet Union through a display of over 50 posters and cartoons. The program included talks, tours, and workshops.
